Award.AwardTitle: Rural Migrant Children in Urban Schools

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
The study examines the process by which rural-to-urban migration generates and sustains new forms of education segregation in urban areas. The project highlights whether and how urban schools exacerbate educational inequality when the rural-urban divide is brought into urban schools. More generally, the project uses the Chinese case to provide insights to inform Western theories on education segregation, which were developed when school segregation was already well in place.

Since the mid-1980s China has seen increasing influx of rural people to cities for manufacturing and service jobs. This migration was first temporary and the children remained at home to go to rural schools. More recently, migrants have moved to cities permanently and many have brought their children along. However, children of rural migrants have limited access to urban public education because of the law linking migrant students' educational right to their rural home. The PI hypothesizes that new forms of educational segregation are emerging as a consequence of the large influx of rural migrant children into the urban education system. To learn about the causes, processes and consequences of this emergent education segregation in urban schools, systematic and longitudinal data and a rigorous analysis of these data are needed. The project will augment an upcoming nationally representative survey of Chinese 7th graders who will be followed over time, the Chinese Education Panel Studies (CEPS). Data will be collected from a supplemental sample of 6,400 seventh graders in 80 urban schools that primarily serve rural migrant children. In addition, a set of survey questions will be added to the CEPS core questionnaire regarding rural migrant children's school process in urban schools. Using the data from the augmented CEPS, investigators will document and explain the extent to which rural migrant children's access to urban education is limited and how teachers and peers treat them differently from urban students. These examinations will provide evidence for whether and how new forms of education segregation emerge and are sustained and rural migrant children are marginalized.

Broader Impacts

This project's data collection is efficient as it piggybacks on an upcoming national, longitudinal survey of students, benefiting from its sampling design, field preparation, fixed costs, and comprehensive core contents. The project will make a significant contribution to data and research infrastructure by adding a sample of 6,400 students in 80 schools. As a result, the project makes access to data on a total of 66,400 students in 830 schools to the U.S. research community. During the project duration U.S. graduate and undergraduate students will be trained to use theoretical and methodological tools from the Western literature to study educational inequality in China.

POR.DRECONTENT:
A deeper understanding of how educational inequality evolves during mass education expansion, speedy economic development, unprecedented rural-urban migration, and rapid social change can imply policy priorities to reduce inequality in human capital formation of succeeding generations. The China case today presents a unique opportunity to advance our understanding. Given the scarce good-quality data in China, the primary objective of this project is to collect nationally representative, longitudinal data for evidence-based research. We have accomplished this goal by providing the public-use baseline data of China Education Panel Survey (CEPS) (available at http://ruc.ceps.edu.cn) on 20,000 7th and 9th graders in 448 classrooms, 112 schools in the 2013-2014 academic year. This CEPS baseline data is globally accessible with all relevant documents in English. In addition, the complete three-wave longitudinal data of CEPS 7th graders will be available for public use after the Wave-3 data collection is completed in 2016 and the cleaning, editing, and documenting later waves data are completed in 2017-2018.

 

This project also offers important findings from preliminary analyses of the CEPS data. First, our analysis provides the first strong and consistent evidence to support two central points. China’s high enrollment rates in compulsory education should not conceal the astonishing disparities in learning opportunities and developmental outcomes between rural-origin and urban-origin children. In addition, the spatial redistribution of compulsory education inequality due to rural-urban migration debunks the popular thought that compulsory education inequality is a development issue. Second, our analysis of the cognitive skills of middle-school students suggests a unique China pattern where little educational improvement is gained from rural-urban migration, contradictory to the prediction of modernization and migration theories. Processes contributing to this China pattern include (1) rural children having migrated with parents are placed in urban schools of poorer learning environment that lower their learning motivations and outcomes; (2) migrants’ children left behind in rural schools suffer from severe parent-child separation; and (3) China’s middle schools, regardless of urban or rural, high- or low-quality, fail to address disadvantaged students’ need and largely reproduce inequality.

 

The project makes three important contributions to our social science knowledge. First, as educational inequality is increasing in China, this project’s primary effort of collecting nationally representative, high quality, school-based data (CEPS) is timely and significant. It provides invaluable data on the changing educational opportunities during rapid social change. The national, longitudinal data we collected and made available for public use will permit testing the hypothesis that once educational segregation comes into being, it becomes institutionalized and resists changes. This knowledge is evidence-based and thus has important implications for not only China but also all societies undergoing rapid social change. Second, the project highlights the organizational strategies of school institution in exacerbating educational inequality when the children of migrants are attending urban public schools. Our school-based CEPS data provide unparalleled information to examine this endogenous institutional change. Third, our project has reformulated western theories for an application to the Chinese case and then used the Chinese case to provide feedback to improve Western theories.
